awd_titl_txt: CICI: RSARC: Infrastructure Support for Securing Large-Scale Scientific Workflows
awd_abstract_narration:
The scientific workflow is an important paradigm for automating and accelerating data processing and sharing in the scientific community. The correctness of scientific discoveries relies on the trustworthiness and reliability of the data processed by scientific workflows and the underlying cyberinfrastructure. Unfortunately, modern scientific workflow systems lack robust infrastructure support for the trustworthy execution of scientific workflows and for the protection of the data processed by such workflows. A scientist or student may forge or alter datasets or computation simply to get papers accepted for publication. A malicious user may also publish forged workflow data on websites, misleading other scientists into investigating and publishing invalid results. This project aims to support a community of engineers and scientists to collaboratively and securely collect, analyze, and share data using scientific workflows.  The success of this project contributes significantly to the national cyberinfrastructure vision of securing the scientific discovery process for a wide range of science and engineering disciplines.

This project develops infrastructure support for secure execution of scientific workflows, detection of anomalous execution flows, and protection of scientific data.  In particular, this project: (1) develops a trusted execution environment for scientific workflows leveraging the Intel Software Guard Extension (SGX) to protect the execution of scientific workflows as well as the data processed by scientific workflows; (2) produces encrypted, tamper-proof, and non-repudiable block-graphs that enable scientists to verify the origin of scientific data and examine how a piece of data was modified and distributed; and (3) develops a machine-learning based anomaly detection technique to detect anomalous execution flows based on logs collected by the underlying cyberinfrastructure.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop novel techniques to protect the research cyberinfrastructure across every stage of scientific workflows executed in distributed environments. The outcomes of this project are summarized below.

(1) Trusted execution environment: We have developed trusted execution environments to protect the execution of scientific workflows as well as the data processed by scientific workflows. In particular, we have (1) compared the functionality, security, and performance of Intel Software Guard Extensions (SGX) and AMD memory encryption technique, (2) developed SecDATAVIEW, an SGX-based trusted execution environment to protect scientific workflows and workflow data, and (3) developed a secure execution environment for GPU workload on scientific workflows. SecDATAVIEW has been integrated with the DATAVIEW scientific workflow system. SecDATAVIEW has been made publicly available at: https://github.com/shiyonglu/SecDATAVIEW.

(2) Block-chain based tamper-proof provenance storage: We have developed SciBlock, an encrypted, tamper-proof, and non-repudiable block-graphs that enable scientists to verify the origin of scientific data and examine how a piece of data was modified and distributed. We have also developed a security framework for scientific workflow provenance access control policies.

(3) Machine/Deep learning based security mechanisms: We have developed RAMP, a real-time machine learning based anomaly detection mechanism for scientific workflows and studied the robustness of deep-learning based anomaly detection models by developing real-time evasion attacks (LAM) and countermeasures. We have also developed CFGExplainer, an explainer to interpret the results of deep-learning based security models. The source code of RAMP, LAM, and CFGExplainer have been made publicly available:

  • RAMP: https://github.com/dherath/RAMP

  • LAM: https://github.com/dherath/Log_Anomaly_Mask

  • CFGExplainer: https://github.com/dherath/CFGExplainer

In addition, we have developed techniques and infrastructure-level support for GPU-enabled deep learning in DATAVIEW, which has been included in the latest DATAVIEW release: https://github.com/shiyonglu/DATAVIEW/releases

(4) Confidential big data workflow scheduling algorithms: We have surveyed scientific workflow scheduling algorithms in the era of big data and developed a confidential big data workflow scheduling algorithm with Intel SGX under deadline constraints.

(5) Student training and course (module) development: This project trains students in the areas of scientific workflows, SGX, cybersecurity, blockchain, and machine/deep learning. Over 20 students were involved in this project. PI Yang has developed a new course "CS680H Blockchain Technology and Its Applications". PI Yang and Co-PI Yan have also added a module on blockchain in their "CS458/CS558 Introduction to Computer Security" course.  Co-PI Yan has added a course module on machine learning based anomaly detection techniques in his "CS559 Science for Cybersecurity" course. In addition, PI Yang added course projects on machine learning based security techniques in her "CS458/CS558 Introduction to Computer Security" course. 

(6) Publications and Ph.D. dissertations: to date, this project resulted in 18 peer-reviewed publications and one paper under review. Most papers were published in reputed conferences or journals such as International Conference on Dependable Systems and Networks (DSN), IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing, IEEE International Conference on Big Data, ACM Conference on Data and Application Security and Privacy, IEEE Transactions on Services Computing, IEEE Conference on Services Computing, IEEE Infocom, IEEE International Conference on Collaboration and Internet, Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC), IEEE Symposium on Security & Privacy, and the Hardware and Architectural Support for Security and Privacy workshop. To date, the papers resulting from this project have received over 200 citations.

This project has also resulted in two Ph.D. dissertations: 

- Jerome D Herath (graduated in May 2022), "Empowering Artificial Intelligence for Cybersecurity Applications".

- Saeid Mofrad (graduated in May 2022), "Securing Big Data Scientific Workflows & GPGPU Computation in the Commodity Cloud with Hardware-assisted Trusted Execution Environments".
